{{for|other references to opera in Chicago|List of opera houses in Chicago}} [[File:Civic Opera House 060528.jpg|thumb|Exterior of the Civic Opera House]] '''Lyric Opera of Chicago''' is one of the leading [[opera]] companies in the United States. It was founded in [[Chicago]] in 1954, under the name 'Lyric Theatre of Chicago' by [[Carol Fox (Chicago opera)|Carol Fox]], [[Nicolà Rescigno]] and Lawrence Kelly, with a season that included [[Maria Callas]]'s American debut in ''[[Norma (opera)|Norma]]''. The company was re-organized by Fox in 1956 under its present name and, after her 1981 departure, it has continued to be of one of the major opera companies in the United States. The Lyric is housed in the [[Civic Opera Building]], which the company now owns.
==Opera in Chicago 1850–1954== The first opera to be performed in Chicago was Bellini's ''[[La sonnambula]]'', presented by a traveling opera company on 29 July 1850.<ref>Preston 1993, p. ??: "One measure of ''La sonnambula'' 's popularity is the fact that it was the first opera to be performed in Chicago."</ref> Chicago's first opera house opened in 1865 but was destroyed in the [[Great Fire of Chicago]] in 1871. The second opera house, the [[Chicago Auditorium]], opened in 1889.<ref>"Chicago Opera" in ''The Encyclopedia Americana'' (1973), Volume 1: "Chicago's first opera house opened in 1865 but was destroyed in the Great Fire five years later. A new house, the Auditorium, opened in 1889"</ref>
In 1929 the current [[Civic Opera House]] on 20 North Wacker Drive was opened, though the [[Chicago Civic Opera]] Company itself collapsed in the [[Great Depression]]. The old Auditorium continued to produce stage shows and musicals till it closed in 1941.<ref>Zeitz, p. 93: "In 1929 it relinquished its role as Chicago's premier opera house to the new Civic Opera Building (see p. 95). But six years earlier,... ''Hellzapoppin'' was the last show to grace the stage before the Auditorium closed in 1941."</ref>
Resident opera companies began in Chicago in 1910 with the [[Chicago Grand Opera Company]] being formed from the remains of the Manhattan Opera Company, which had been founded by Oscar Hammerstein I, and had been squeezed out by the more financially sound Metropolitan Opera. Chicago had this first company for four seasons, then, after no season in 1914/15, it was re-formed as the [[Chicago Opera Association]]. This lasted through 1921/22, when it became the [[Chicago Civic Opera]] from 1922 until 1932. After no season in 1932/33, the company was re-formed and again named the Chicago Grand Opera Company from 1933 to 1935. From 1936 to 1939, the company was called [[Chicago City Opera Company]], and finally from 1940 to 1946 opera was presented by the [[Chicago Opera Company]]. There were no seasons from 1947 until 1953, so opera was presented by other companies on tour. Lyric Opera was formed in 1954 and has continued uninterrupted except for 1967.
==Lyric Opera, 1954 to 1980== Carol Fox, America's first female opera impresario at the age of 28, began her first season in 1954 by bringing [[Maria Callas]] for her American debut in the title role of ''[[Norma (opera)|Norma]]'', the first of many electrifying Callas performances in Chicago. However, this first eight-opera season in 1954 was not the result of a long apprenticeship in opera production; Carol Fox, fluent in Italian and French, had studied opera singing for many years, culminating in two years of intensive work in Italy. However, when she realized that performance was not to be in her future, she decided that it lay in bringing the performances of the world's finest artists to her home town of Chicago. Her success can be measured in one statistic regarding the filling of the Lyric's Civic Opera House: in 1954, the season ran for three weeks; in 2007/08 the Lyric had an almost six-month season.
Fox also used her formidable persuasive powers on artists other than singers: she was able to bring [[Rudolph Nureyev]] to make his debut on an American opera stage at the Lyric; [[Vera Zorina]], [[Alicia Markova]], [[Erik Bruhn]] and [[Maria Tallchief]] also danced at the Lyric, and [[George Balanchine]] created choreography for the Lyric. The Italian composer [[Pino Donati]] was her artistic director. [[Bruno Bartoletti]] was principal conductor, but other conductors included [[Tullio Serafin]], [[Dimitri Mitropoulos]] and [[Artur Rodzinski]]. [[Christoph von Dohnányi]] and Sir [[Georg Solti]] chose the Lyric for their American operatic debuts. [[Franco Zeffirelli]] staged operas as did [[Harold Prince]].
Because of her illnesses and her refusal to lower her artistic standards despite the Lyric's dire financial state in 1980, her resignation was sought and given. Carol Fox died a few months later, survived by a daughter Victoria.
It was of the Lyric's founder that [[Saul Bellow]] wrote in 1979 "Miss Fox will be remembered, together with Jane Addams of Hull House and Harriet Monroe of Poetry magazine, as one of Chicago's greatest women."<ref>Cassidy, Claudia, foreword by Saul Bellow, ''Lyric Opera of Chicago'', The Opera,1979, {{ISBN|0960353801}}</ref>
Throughout the many years at the Lyric, Carol Fox developed the confidence and authority to bring world-famous artists to the Lyric: [[Luciano Pavarotti]] (56 performances in 7 roles), [[Tito Gobbi]], [[Eleanor Steber]], [[Jussi Björling]], [[Birgit Nilsson]], [[Renata Tebaldi]], [[Giuseppe Di Stefano]], [[Giulietta Simionato]], [[Richard Tucker]], [[Boris Christoff]], [[Eileen Farrell]], [[Dorothy Kirsten]], [[Leonie Rysanek]], [[Leontyne Price]], [[Elisabeth Schwarzkopf]], [[Geraint Evans]], [[Mirella Freni]], [[Nicolai Ghiaurov]], [[Alfredo Kraus]], [[Renata Scotto]], [[Robert Merrill]], [[Joan Sutherland]], [[Christa Ludwig]], [[Jon Vickers]], [[Marilyn Horne]], [[Grace Bumbry]], [[Montserrat Caballé]], [[Tatiana Troyanos]], [[Sherrill Milnes]], [[Plácido Domingo]], [[Felicia Weathers]] and [[José Carreras]]. [[Anna Moffo]] also chose the Lyric for her American debut.
==Later administrations, 1981 to the present== Carol Fox was succeeded at the Lyric by her longtime assistant manager, [[Ardis Krainik]] (1981–1996), after whom the opera house was named, and then by William Mason (1997–2011). [[Anthony Freud]] took over in October 2011.
Sir [[Andrew Davis (conductor)|Andrew Davis]] is Lyric's music director and principal conductor, a post he has occupied since in September 2000. He led three complete cycles of ''[[Der Ring des Nibelungen]]'' in the 2004/05 season to mark the company's 50th anniversary. [[Danny Newman]] was the company's long-time press agent from 1954 until his retirement in the 2001/02 season; Newman is largely credited as the founder of subscription-based arts marketing, the standard economic model for not-for-profit arts organizations in the US.<ref>Bruce Weber, [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9904EFDD153BF930A1575AC0A961958260 "Arts in America; The Unsung Hero of Nonprofit Theater Is Still Selling"], ''The New York Times'', 23 December 1997</ref> [[Philip David Morehead]] was head of music staff until his retirement in 2015.
==Production history== In addition to the [[List of famous operas|standard operatic repertoire]], Lyric also presents contemporary works. Recent productions have included [[John Harbison|Harbison's]] ''[[The Great Gatsby#Opera|The Great Gatsby]]'' (2000–2001), [[Kurt Weill|Weill's]] ''[[Street Scene (opera)|Street Scene]]'' (2001–2002), [[Carlisle Floyd|Floyd's]] ''[[Susannah]]'', [[Stephen Sondheim|Sondheim's]] ''[[Sweeney Todd (musical)|Sweeney Todd]]'' (2002–2003), and [[John Adams]]' ''[[Doctor Atomic]]'' directed by Peter Sellars.
Composer [[William Bolcom]] wrote his most recent opera for Lyric, ''[[A Wedding (opera)|A Wedding]]'', based on the 1978 film of the same name directed by [[Robert Altman]]. It premiered during Lyric's 50th-anniversary season. During the 2015/16 season, the company premiered its latest commission, ''[[Bel Canto (opera)|Bel Canto]]'' by Peruvian composer [[Jimmy López]] with a libretto by [[Nilo Cruz]] based on the novel by [[Ann Patchett]].
The Lyric Opera productions were broadcast and nationally syndicated by [[WFMT]] Radio Network, from 1971 until 2001. The broadcasts ceased then because of a loss of sponsorship <ref>Sponsors' Withdrawal Ends Lyric Opera Radio Show: John von Rhein, Chicago Tribune, September 13, 2002</ref>. The issue was resolved at the 11th hour for the October 21, 2006 premiere of [[Richard Strauss]]'s opera ''[[Salome (opera)|Salome]]'' starring [[Deborah Voigt]]. Syndicated broadcast of the Lyric Opera resumed in May 2007 on the [[WFMT]] network, which was included on [[XM Satellite Radio]] before it merged and became SiriusXM Radio. Syndicated broadcast of the Lyric Opera resumed in May 2007 on the [[WFMT]] network, which was included on [[XM Satellite Radio]] before it merged and became SiriusXM Radio.
==Civic Opera House== [[File:Lyric Opera of Chicago interior.jpg|250px|thumb|The Ardis Krainik Theatre]] :''For details, see [[Civic Opera House (Chicago)|Civic Opera House]]''
The company's permanent home is the [[Civic Opera House (Chicago)|Civic Opera House]], a building which it rented from 1954 until after the 1993 renovations. It is a 1929 structure with an [[Art Deco]] interior. Its 3,563-seat capacity makes it the second-largest opera auditorium in [[North America]] after the [[Metropolitan Opera|Metropolitan Opera House]] in New York City. The interior was named ''The Ardis Krainik Theatre'' in 1996 in honor of Ardis Krainik, the former General Director, who was responsible for its renovation from 1993 onwards.
===Joffrey Ballet===
In 2017, Lyric Opera of Chicago as house manager of the theater announced that the [[Joffrey Ballet]] plans to move from its longtime performance venue at the [[Auditorium Theatre]] to the opera house in 2020.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/theater/ct-ae-lyric-joffrey-jones-1001-story.html |title=How the Lyric and Joffrey's new partnership will change cultural Chicago |last=Jones |first=Chris |work=chicagotribune.com |access-date=2017-12-22 |language=en-US}}</ref> The announcement coincided with the Lyric’s presentation of a new production of [[Christoph Willibald Gluck|Gluck's]] ''[[Orfeo ed Euridice]]'' by choreographer [[John Neumeier]]; the production fused the musical and ballet elements of the opera and featured the Joffrey Ballet.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/theater/reviews/ct-ent-lyric-joffrey-orphee-review-20170924-story.html|title=Review: Triumphant new 'Orphee' presages strong partnership of Lyric Opera, Joffrey Ballet|last=von Rhein|first=John|date=September 24, 2017|work=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=12 March 2018}}</ref>
==The Patrick G. and Shirley W. Ryan Opera Center== The Patrick G. and Shirley W. Ryan Opera Center (formerly Lyric Opera Center for American Artists, 1981–2006), established in 1974 by Carol Fox, is the professional artist-development program for Lyric Opera of Chicago.
The Ryan Opera Center is considered one of the most prestigious vocal programs in America,<ref name="ketterson">Ketterson, Mark Thomas, [https://web.archive.org/web/20080516062610/http://www.usoperaweb.com/2003/autum/locaa.html "Lyric Opera Center of American Artists Trains the Opera Singers of the Future]", on usoperaweb.com, Autumn 2003</ref> and has produced notable singers, including: {{Div col|rules=yes|colwidth=18em}} *[[Harolyn Blackwell]] *[[Nicole Cabell]] *[[Mark S. Doss]] *[[Elizabeth Futral]] *[[Joseph Kaiser]] *[[Gary Lehman]] *[[Emily Magee]] *[[Susanna Phillips]] *[[Matthew Polenzani]] *[[Erin Wall]] *[[Yang Guang (mezzo-soprano)|Guang Yang]] {{div col end}}
Approximately a dozen young singers are selected from the near 400 who audition annually,<ref>[http://www.lyricopera.org/about/ryanopera.aspx The Patrick G. and Shirley W. Ryan Opera Center website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091016025244/http://www.lyricopera.org/about/ryanopera.aspx |date=2009-10-16 }}</ref> and they are in residence for twelve months. Over the course of the year they receive advanced instruction in numerous aspects of operatic performance, including voice lessons and coachings, language and acting training, and master classes with some of opera’s most renowned artists. The singers gain valuable performing experience by participating in recitals and concerts at many Chicago-area venues. During Lyric Opera’s mainstage season, they perform and understudy roles at all levels. The singers work with the world’s greatest opera singers, conductors, and directors, thus advancing the young artists’ professionalism. In 2005, author [[William Murray (writer)|William Murray]] wrote a book about a year in the life of an entering class at the Ryan Opera Center.<ref>See Murray, William 2006, ''Fortissimo: Backstage at the Opera with Sacred Monsters and Young Singers''</ref>
[[Andrew Foldi]] was Director of the Ryan Opera Center from 1991 to 1995. He was succeeded by [[Richard Pearlman]], who was Director of the program from 1995 until his death in 2006. Renowned soprano [[Gianna Rolandi]], who had been the Ryan Opera Center's Director of Vocal Studies and principal instructor since 2002, was appointed Director of the program in 2006.<ref>[http://www.operanews.com/Opera_News_Magazine/2006/5/News/Gianna_Rolandi_Named_as_New_Lyric_Opera_Center_for_American_Artists_Director.html "Gianna Rolandi Named as New Lyric Opera Center for American Artists Director"], ''[[Opera News]]''. May 9, 2006]</ref> The program is now administered by Dan Novak, Director; Craig Terry, Music Director; Julia Faulkner, Director of Vocal Studies, and [[Renée Fleming]], Advisor.

A film '''Production Office''' is the administrative office responsible for managing a [[film production]]. The office is responsible to the [[film producer|Film Producer]] and includes the [[production manager|Production Manager]], [[Assistant director|Assistant Director]] and one or more [[Production assistant|Production Assistants]]. Typically a ''Production Office'' is established in the [[pre-production]] phase and continues until at least [[post-production]].
The Production Office usually includes positions such as, but not entirely made of, Production Supervisor, Production Office Coordinator, Assistant Production Office Coordinator, Production Secretary and Office Assistants (otherwise known or credited as Office PA's or Staff Assistants).
A Production Office will look different for each production depending on many variables including the type of film, the production company producing the film and the size of the budget of the film itself. A Production Office can be as small as one or two people (mostly seen in an independent film structure) or as big as ten or more on a film with a sizeable budget. <ref>http://woman.thenest.com/average-salary-office-manager-film-production-company-18686.html thenest.com The Average Salary of an Office Manager in the Film Production Company by Dana Severson, Demand Media </ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2014}} {{Use British English|date=November 2014}} {{Infobox Organization |name = Rimbaud and Verlaine Foundation |image =Rimbaud_and_Verlaine_Foundation_logo.jpg |image_border = |size = |caption = |map = |msize = |mcaption = |abbreviation = |motto = |formation = 2011 |extinction = |type = Arts and culture |status = [[Charitable organization|Registered charity]] |purpose = Using inspiration from Rimbaud and Verlaine to encourage engagement with the arts, widening appreciation for the arts, championing the importance of the arts in education and social capital building, and making the arts more financially resilient and sustainable |headquarters = [[London]] |location = [[Kings Place]], [[King's Cross, London]] |region_served= |membership = |leader_title = Chief Executive|leader_name = [[Graham Henderson (cultural entrepreneur)|Graham Henderson]] |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = {{url|http://www.rimbaudverlaine.org/}} |remarks = }}
[[File:Kings Place.jpg|thumb|150px|[[Kings Place]] from across the canal]] The '''Rimbaud and Verlaine Foundation''' is a [[registered charity]]<ref name= "Open">{{cite web | url=http://opencharities.org/charities/1157063 | title=Rimbaud and Verlaine Foundation | publisher=Open Charities | date=17 May 2014 | accessdate=18 November 2014}} Registered charity number 1157063</ref> in the [[United Kingdom]]. It was set up in 2011 to take advantage of the gift, in a legacy, of the property at [[Royal College Street|8 Royal College Street]] in the [[London Borough of Camden]], the house occupied by the French poets [[Arthur Rimbaud]] and [[Paul Verlaine]]<ref name="About">{{cite web | url=http://www.rimbaudverlaine.org/en/about-us/about-foundation/ | title=About Us | publisher=Rimbaud and Verlaine Foundation | accessdate=18 November 2014}}</ref><ref name="Poetry house"/> when they lived in London in 1873. In 2014 it was launched as a new arts organisation and a registered charity.<ref name= "Open"/>
The Foundation’s long-term aim is to develop 8 Royal College Street as a European-style "poetry house".<ref name="Poetry house">{{cite web | url=http://www.rimbaudverlaine.org/en/poetry-house/ | title=Poetry House | publisher=Rimbaud and Verlaine Foundation | accessdate=1 March 2018}}</ref> In the meantime, it is using the two poets as an inspirational starting point for a much wider mission to champion arts and culture. Exploring the vital role played by the arts in education, [[social capital]] building and cultural exchange, the Foundation is also developing a new and more sustainable business model for the arts, based around earned income.
==Governance== [[File:Graham Henderson portrait.png|thumb|150px|Portrait of Graham Henderson]] The Foundation is managed by a board of English-speaking and French-speaking trustees, chaired by Thomas Venning, head of Books and Manuscripts at [[Christie’s]].<ref name="Governance">{{cite web | url=http://www.rimbaudverlaine.org/en/about-us/board-corporate-governance/ | title=Corporate governance | publisher=Rimbaud and Verlaine Foundation | accessdate=1 March 2018}}</ref> Its chief executive (since April 2014) is [[Graham Henderson (cultural entrepreneur)|Graham Henderson]],<ref name="Journey">{{cite web | url=http://www.rimbaudverlaine.org/en/news/rimbaud-and-verlaine-embark-journey/ | title=Rimbaud and Verlaine embark on a journey | author=[[Graham Henderson (cultural entrepreneur)|Henderson, Graham]]|publisher=Rimbaud and Verlaine Foundation | date=7 January 2015 | accessdate=5 April 2018}}</ref> who was previously chief executive of [[Poet in the City]].<ref name="Leaving">{{cite web | url=http://www.artsprofessional.co.uk/magazine/271/faces/graham-henderson-leaves-poet-city | title=Graham Henderson leaves Poet in the City | work=Arts Professional | date=6 March 2014 | accessdate=11 April 2014}}</ref>
==History== [[File:8 Royal College Street, Camden Town - geograph.org.uk - 430128.jpg|thumb|150px|8 [[Royal College Street]] in 2007, before restoration]] [[File:8 Royal College Street.jpg|thumb|150px|8 Royal College Street in 2015, after restoration]] The Foundation was created by Graham Henderson and was initially incubated within Poet in the City.<ref>{{cite magazine | url=http://www.3ammagazine.com/3am/chasing-rimbaud/ | work=[[3:AM Magazine]]|location= Paris|title= Chasing Rimbaud | date=7 May 2008|accessdate= 1 March 2018}}</ref> Henderson was part of (and inherited) the previous campaign to save the property at 8 Royal College Street. For many years this was run by Gerry Harrison, a [[London Borough of Camden|Camden]] councillor,<ref name="Patterson">{{cite news | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/books/features/verlaine-and-rimbaud-poets-from-hell-525605.html | title=Verlaine and Rimbaud: Poets from hell | work=[[The Independent]] | date=8 February 2006 | accessdate=20 November 2014 | author=Patterson, Christina}}</ref> during the process of which many celebrities have rallied to the cause, including the actor [[Simon Callow]],<ref name="Osley">{{Cite news |url=http://www.thecnj.com/camden/020906/news020906_14.html |title=French are urged to buy poets' home |last=Osley |first=Richard |date=2 September 2006 |work=[[Camden New Journal]] |access-date=22 March 2018}}</ref> the writers [[Julian Barnes]],<ref name="Patterson"/><ref name="Barnes">{{Cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/news/dylan-called-in-to-help-save-poets-love-nest-on-londons-desolation-row-6106333.html |title=Dylan called in to help save poets' love nest on London's Desolation Row |last=Barnes |first=Anthony |date=19 March 2006 |work=[[The Independent]] |access-date=22 March 2018}}</ref> [[Lisa Appignanesi]]<ref name="Patterson"/> and [[Tracy Chevalier]] and the musician [[Patti Smith]].
In 2007 the house was bought and sympathetically restored by a new owner, Michael Corby. Committed to the historic identity of the property, he agreed in 2011 to leave the property as legacy gift to the Rimbaud and Verlaine Foundation, created especially by Graham Henderson for this purpose. The Foundation has always been clear, however, that it does not want to be just a small [[Historic house museum|house museum]]. It has therefore used the idea of the "poetry house" to create an arts organisation with the wider goal of promoting culture and the arts and championing their role in social capital building.<ref name = Venning>{{Cite web |url=https://www.rimbaudverlaine.org/en/new-business-model/are-arts-compatible-pursuit-profit/ |title=Are the arts compatible with the pursuit of profit? |last=Venning |first=Thomas |publisher = Rimbaud and Verlaine Foundation|access-date=24 March 2018}}</ref> This has seen the Foundation deliver an extensive programme of cross-arts events and commissions and take an innovative approach to audience and business development.
==Events==
The programme of events delivered by the Foundation has been intentionally eclectic, involving many different art forms, and up-and-coming talent from across the arts and cultural sector. Amongst other things this programme has included events featuring opera, classical music, sculpture, poetry, literature, theatre, jazz music and rock music. Highlights have included ''The Disappearing Poet'',<ref name="Disappearing">{{Cite web |url=http://discovery.ucl.ac.uk/1453827/ |title=Arthur Rimbaud: the Disappearing Poet |date=2014 |publisher=[[University College London]] |access-date=5 April 2018}}</ref> an event exploring why poets disappear, ''[[Faure|Faure’s Verlaine Settings]]'', an event presenting classical song settings of the poet’s work, and ''Rock for Rimbaud'', a concert featuring Americana artists. Institutional partners have included the [[National Opera Studio]], [[Bloodaxe Books]] and [[Pernod]] Absinthe. From 2018 the Foundation is organising a series of [[Salon (gathering)|salon]]-style events at Blacks Club in [[Soho]] in London, featuring speakers and artists, and designed to champion its work.
==Commissions==
The Foundation has also been responsible for commissioning new work in the arts. For instance, in 2016 it commissioned both a full-length jazz show (''Jazz from the Playing Card Factory'')<ref name="LJN">{{Cite news |url=http://www.londonjazznews.com/2016/09/previewinterview-romanian-pianist-sorin.html |title=PREVIEW/INTERVIEW: Romanian pianist Sorin Zlat (new commission From the Playing Card Factory, Kings Place, 10th October) |date=3 September 2016 |work=London Jazz News |access-date=1 March 2018}}</ref> and a full-length theatre show (''Poetry House Live'').<ref name="Live">{{Cite web |url=https://poetryhouseproject.wordpress.com/ |title=Poetry House Live |website=Poetry House Project |access-date=1 March 2018}}</ref> As well as several performances the latter has resulted in a full-length film made in partnership with the film department at the [[Royal Conservatoire of Scotland]] in [[Glasgow]].<ref name="CCA">{{Cite web |url=https://www.cca-glasgow.com/programme/scottish-writers-centre-poetry-house-adapting-poetic-text-for-the-big-screen |title=Scottish Writers' Centre Poetry House – Adapting Poetic Text for the Big Screen |year=2017 |publisher=[[Centre for Contemporary Arts]] |location=Glasgow |access-date=3 March 2018}}</ref> The Foundation has also been responsible for an original poetry commission involving a suite of poems by [[George Szirtes]], and a series of 24 paintings by the artist Rebecca Taber inspired by the poetry of Rimbaud and Verlaine. In 2018 the Foundation is seeking funding for, amongst other things, an original [[chamber opera]], and an original [[puppet show]].
==Educational work==
The Rimbaud and Verlaine Foundation is committed to encouraging new generations of students in secondary schools in the UK to engage with the arts and literature, and to gain an international perspective. In particular, it seeks to engage with young people in local Camden and [[London Borough of Islington |Islington]] schools, located within a short distance of the property at 8 Royal College Street, many of whom come from socially and economically deprived backgrounds. The Foundation wants to provide these young people with experiences and educational opportunities they might otherwise not possess. This charitable mission lies at the heart of the Foundation’s identity, and forms an important part of its contribution to the local community.
In 2017, the Foundation delivered an extensive programme of educational placements featuring poetry in four schools in the London Borough of Camden, working with students from [[Maria Fidelis Roman Catholic Convent School]], [[Regent High School]], [[Camden School for Girls]]<ref name="Camden Girls">{{Cite web |url=http://www.camdengirls.camden.sch.uk/news/?pid=1183&nid=115&storyid=1222 |title=A Celebration of Poetry |last=Fearnside |first=Angie |date= 2017|access-date= 25 March 2018 |publisher=[[Camden School for Girls]]}}</ref><ref name="Celebration">{{Cite web |url=http://www.camdengirls.camden.sch.uk/_files/342DF6759B4B7EC3E2E984C6F39A7A9F.pdf |title=A Celebration of Poetry |last=Fearnside |first=Angie |date=2017|access-date= 25 March 2018 |publisher=[[Camden School for Girls]]}}</ref> and [[La Sainte Union Catholic School]] in a programme that involved over 500 students. This schools programme was generously supported by the [[T.S. Eliot]] Foundation. As well as work in the classroom, it included school shows and the publication of an 89-page poetry [[anthology]] entitled ''How We Make Daylight'', featuring work by the students.<ref name="Camden Girls"/>
The Foundation is facilitating a repeat programme of schools’ placements in Camden in 2018, with poetry in translation as its main focus, which will be delivered by Modern Poetry in Translation.
==International connections== [[File:Kindred Spirits.jpg|thumb|200px|Delegates attending Kindred Spirits conference in [[Bucharest]], 2015]] The Foundation has also been working internationally. In 2015 Graham Henderson and the organisation took the lead in creating the Kindred Spirits network of European poetry houses including seven arts organisations based in six different European countries.<ref name="Kindred">{{Cite web |url=http://www.kindredspirits.eu/ |title=Welcome to Kindred Spirits|website=Kindred Spirits|accessdate = 3 March 2018}}</ref> The Foundation’s partners include the Rimbaud Museum in [[Charleville-Mézières]], La Maison de la Poesie in Paris, [[Residencia de Estudiantes]] in Madrid, the Lorca Foundation in [[Granada]], the Keats-Shelley House in Rome, the National Museum of Literature in Bucharest, the [[Druskininkai#Culture|Druskininkai Poetic Fall]] festival in Lithuania and the [[Halldór Laxness]] Museum in Iceland.<ref name="Kindred partner">{{Cite web |url=http://www.kindredspirits.eu/partner-pages/ |title=Partners |website=Kindred Spirits |access-date=3 March 2018}}</ref> The network became a vehicle for an application for a [[European Union]] Large Cooperation Grant in the autumn of that year. The Foundation was all set to resubmit its application in 2016, with every chance of success, when the [[United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016 |referendum result]] in favour of [[Brexit]] intervened. As a result, the charity's trustees decided that it was no longer sensible to place EU funding at the centre of the organisation’s future strategy. The Foundation, nevertheless, is keen to build on the relationships it had established with its "poetry house" partners, and particularly on the experience of the conference held in [[Bucharest]] in May 2015, bringing together representatives from all of the partner organisations.<ref name="House">{{Cite web |url=http://www.kindredspirits.eu/news/poetry-house/ |title=The Poetry House |author= [[Graham Henderson (cultural entrepreneur)|Henderson, Graham]] |date=May 2015 |website=Kindred Spirits|accessdate = 3 March 2018}}</ref> The Poetry House Live theatre show in 2017 was commissioned expressly with the purpose of involving talented up-and-coming playwrights from all of the seven countries involved in the network.

'''Sandra Annette Bullock''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|b|ʊ|l|ə|k}}; born July 26, 1964)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/sandra_bullock/|title=Sandra Bullock: Snapshot|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|accessdate=February 14, 2016}}</ref> is an American actress, producer, and philanthropist. After making her acting debut with a minor role in the thriller ''[[Hangmen (film)|Hangmen]]'' (1987), she received early attention for her performance in the sci-fi action film ''[[Demolition Man (film)|Demolition Man]]'' (1993). Her breakthrough came in the action thriller ''[[Speed (1994 film)|Speed]]'' (1994). A line of successful films followed throughout the 1990s, including ''[[While You Were Sleeping (film)|While You Were Sleeping]]'' (1995), ''[[The Net (1995 film)|The Net]]'' (1995), ''[[A Time to Kill (1996 film)|A Time to Kill]]'' (1996), and ''[[Hope Floats]]'' (1998).
Bullock achieved further success in the following decades in ''[[Miss Congeniality (film)|Miss Congeniality]]'' (2000), ''[[Two Weeks Notice]]'' (2002), ''[[Crash (2004 film)|Crash]]'' (2004), ''[[The Proposal (2009 film)|The Proposal]]'' (2009), ''[[The Heat (film)|The Heat]]'' (2013), and ''[[Ocean's 8]]'' (2018). She was awarded the [[Academy Award for Best Actress]] and the [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress in a Motion Picture – Drama|Golden Globe Award for Best Actress in a Drama]] for playing [[Leigh Anne Tuohy]] in the biographical drama ''[[The Blind Side (film)|The Blind Side]]'' (2009), and was nominated in the same categories for her performance in the thriller ''[[Gravity (2013 film)|Gravity]]'' (2013). Bullock's greatest commercial success is the animated comedy ''[[Minions (film)|Minions]]'' (2015), which grossed over [[United States dollar|US$]]1 billion at the box office.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=minions.htm|title=Minions (2015)|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]. [[Amazon.com]]|accessdate=August 31, 2015}}</ref> In 2007, she was one of Hollywood's highest-paid actresses,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/2007/01/17/richest-women-entertainment-tech-media-cz_lg_richwomen07_0118womenstars_lander.html|title=The 20 Richest Women in Entertainment|last=Goldman|first=Lea|author2=Blakeley, Kiri |date= January 18, 2007|work=Forbes|accessdate=January 6, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Erenza |first=Jen |title=Justin Bieber, Miranda Cosgrove, & Lady Gaga Are Welcomed into 2012 Guinness World Records |url=http://ryanseacrest.com/2011/09/14/justin-bieber-miranda-cosgrove-lady-gaga-are-welcomed-into-2012-guinness-world-records/ |publisher=RyanSeacrest.com |accessdate=September 16, 2011 |date=September 14, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110925171516/http://ryanseacrest.com/2011/09/14/justin-bieber-miranda-cosgrove-lady-gaga-are-welcomed-into-2012-guinness-world-records/ |archivedate=September 25, 2011}}</ref> and in 2015, she ranked as the highest-paid actress.<ref>https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/film-news/11012632/Sandra-Bullock-is-Hollywoods-highest-paid-actress.html</ref> She was also named "Most Beautiful Woman" by ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' magazine in 2015.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/people-2015-beautiful-sandra-bullock-790747|title=Sandra Bullock Named People Magazine's 'Most Beautiful Woman'|first=Hilary|last=Lewis|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=April 22, 2015|accessdate=April 22, 2015}}</ref>
In addition to her acting career, Bullock is the founder of the production company Fortis Films. She has produced some of the films in which she starred, including ''[[Miss Congeniality 2: Armed and Fabulous]]'' (2005) and ''[[All About Steve]]'' (2009). She was an executive producer of the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] sitcom ''[[George Lopez (TV series)|George Lopez]]'' (2002–07), and made several appearances during its run.
== Early life == Bullock was born in [[Arlington County, Virginia|Arlington, Virginia]]. Her father, John W. Bullock (1925–2018), was a [[United States Army]] employee and part-time voice coach; her mother, Helga Mathilde Meyer (1942–2000), was an opera singer and voice teacher.<ref>[http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.com/~battle/celeb/bullock.htm ''Sandra Bullock genealogy'']. RootsWeb. [[Ancestry.com]]. Retrieved June 27, 2013.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/84/Sandra-Bullock.html |title=''Sandra Bullock Biography''|publisher=Film Reference|accessdate=March 5, 2010}}</ref> Helga was German, while John is from [[Birmingham, Alabama]].<ref>[http://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/ireland/cwgbeyauqlgb/ "Keanu Reeves loving the World Cup"]. ''[[Irish Examiner]]''. June 20, 2006</ref> Bullock's maternal grandfather was a German rocket scientist from [[Nuremberg]]. John, who was in charge of the [[Military mail#U.S. Military Postal Service|U.S. Army's Military Postal Service]] in Europe, was stationed in Nuremberg when he met Helga. They married in Germany and moved to Arlington, where John worked with the [[United States Army Materiel Command|Army Materiel Command]] before becoming a contractor for [[The Pentagon]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Hamm |first=Liza |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20309116,00.html |title=Sandra Bullock: Mom was the life of the party | newspaper=[[People (magazine)|People]] | date=September 30, 2009 |accessdate=April 14, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Chiu |first=Alexis |url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20061646,00.html|title=Sandra Bullock: 'I have my family' |work=People |date=March 26, 2007 |accessdate=April 14, 2010}}</ref> Bullock has a younger sister, [[Gesine Bullock-Prado]], who went on to serve as vice president of Bullock's production company Fortis Films.<ref name="Bio"/> Until the age of 18, Bullock held American-German [[Multiple citizenship|dual citizenship]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.fr-online.de/spezials/oscar-fuer-sandra-bullock-zimtzicke-mit-haltung,1473358,2703738.html | title=Zimtzicke mit Haltung | work=[[Frankfurter Rundschau]] | date=June 29, 2009 | accessdate=January 16, 2014}}</ref> She then held only American citizenship until 2009, when she reapplied for German citizenship.<ref name="Local"/>
Bullock was raised in Germany (Nuremberg) and Austria ([[Vienna]] and [[Salzburg]])<ref name="Welt profile">{{cite web|url=https://www.welt.de/vermischtes/article1952673/SANDRA-BULLOCK.html|title=Sandra Bullock|work=[[Die Welt]]|date=April 30, 2008|accessdate=December 7, 2016}}</ref> for 12 years, and grew up speaking German.<ref name="Local">{{cite web | url=http://www.thelocal.de/20090629/20277 | title=Sandra Bullock applying for German passport | work=[[The Local]] | date=June 26, 2009 | accessdate=January 16, 2014}}</ref> She attended the humanistic [[Waldorf education|Waldorf School]] in Nuremberg.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.waldorf.net/html/aktuell/kuenstlerischer_unterricht.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101208131432/http://www.waldorf.net/html/aktuell/kuenstlerischer_unterricht.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=December 8, 2010 |title=Ehemalige Waldorfschülerin gewinnt Oscar |publisher=[[Waldorf education|Die Landesarbeitsgemeinschaft der Freien Waldorfschulen]] [[Berlin/Brandenburg Metropolitan Region|Berlin-Brandenburg]] |accessdate=January 16, 2014 |df=}}</ref><ref name="Welt profile"/> As a child, while her mother went on European opera tours, Bullock usually stayed with her aunt Christl and cousin Susanne, the latter of whom would later marry German politician [[Peter Ramsauer]].<ref>"Flash, Die Bilder des Tages – Echt bayerisch", [[Rhein-Zeitung]] on July 11, 2000. Retrieved December 7, 2016</ref> Bullock studied ballet and vocal arts as a child and frequently accompanied her mother, taking small parts in her opera productions. She sang in the opera's children's choir at the [[Staatstheater Nürnberg]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Die Nette von nebenan |publisher=Kino.de |url=http://www.kino.de/mitwirk.php4?typ=filmstarportrait&nr=24935&PHPSESSID=79bcb28af46330971138e0880b77c9b7 |language=German |accessdate=July 15, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050514092453/http://www.kino.de/mitwirk.php4?typ=filmstarportrait&nr=24935&PHPSESSID=98816571faea1374fec030661906c351 |archivedate=May 14, 2005}}</ref> Bullock has a scar above her left eye, caused by falling into a creek when she was a child.<ref>{{cite web|last=Zoe |first=Bauer |title=Celebrities with Scars: Famous Blemishes and the Stories Behind Them |url=http://uk.news.yahoo.com/celebrities-scars-famous-blemishes-stories-behind-them-204500278.html |accessdate=October 15, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131112153048/http://uk.news.yahoo.com/celebrities-scars-famous-blemishes-stories-behind-them-204500278.html |archivedate=November 12, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite episode|series=[[Live! With Kelly and Michael]]|season=1|episode=209|airdate=June 27, 2013|title=Live! With Kelly and Michael|network=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]}}</ref> She attended [[Washington-Lee High School]], where she was a [[Cheerleading|cheerleader]] and performed in high school theater productions. After graduating in 1982, she attended [[East Carolina University]] in [[Greenville, North Carolina]], where she received a [[Bachelor of Fine Arts|BFA]] in Drama in 1987.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Seventy-eighth Annual Commencement of East Carolina University |journal=Commencement Bulletin |date= May 9, 1987 |url=https://digital.lib.ecu.edu/22514 |accessdate=October 23, 2014}}{{failed verification|date=November 2015}}</ref> While at ECU, she performed in multiple theater productions, including ''[[Peter Pan]]'' and ''[[Three Sisters (play)|Three Sisters]]''.<ref>{{cite journal|title= Buccaneer|journal=East Carolina University yearbook |volume=1986 |issue=1 |year= 1986 |url=https://digital.lib.ecu.edu/13326 |accessdate=October 23, 2014}}</ref> She then moved to [[Manhattan]], [[New York (state)|New York]], where she supported herself as a bartender, cocktail waitress, and coat checker while auditioning for roles.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sandra Bullock: 1986|url=http://www.vogue.com/voguepedia/Sandra_Bullock|work=[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]|accessdate=June 30, 2013}}</ref>{{better source|date=July 2015|Vogue source is a slideshow, doesn't support statement}}
== Career == ===Beginnings (1987–1993)=== [[File:Sandra Bullock Cannes.jpg|upright|Bullock at the Cannes Film Festival in 1996|thumb]] While in New York, Bullock took acting classes with [[Sanford Meisner]].<ref name="Bio">{{cite web|title=Sandra Bullock- Biography |url=https://movies.yahoo.com/person/sandra-bullock/biography.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120119002500/http://movies.yahoo.com/person/sandra-bullock/biography.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=January 19, 2012 |publisher=[[Yahoo! Movies]] |accessdate=June 30, 2013 |df=}}</ref> She appeared in several student films, and later landed a role in an Off-Broadway play ''No Time Flat''. Director [[Alan J. Levi]] was impressed by Bullock's performance and offered her a part in the made-for-television film ''[[Bionic Showdown: The Six Million Dollar Man and the Bionic Woman]]'' (1989). This led to her being cast in a series of small roles in several [[independent film]]s as well as in the lead role of the short-lived [[NBC]] television version of the film ''[[Working Girl (TV series)|Working Girl]]'' (1990).<ref>{{cite news|title=Yes, These Movies Became TV Shows...and it Didn't Work Out|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/551820/yes-these-movies-became-tv-shows-and-it-didn-t-work-out|accessdate=November 4, 2015|publisher=E!}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Working Girl|url=http://www.ew.com/article/1990/04/27/working-girl|accessdate=November 4, 2015|work=Entertainment Weekly|date=April 27, 1990}}</ref> She went on to appear in several films, such as ''[[Love Potion No. 9 (film)|Love Potion No. 9]]'' (1992), ''[[The Thing Called Love]]'' (1993) and ''[[Fire on the Amazon]]'' (1993), before rosing to early prominence with her supporting role in the sci-fi action film ''[[Demolition Man (film)|Demolition Man]]'' (1993).
===Worldwide exposure (1994–1999)=== Bullock's big breakthrough came in 1994, when she starred in the action thriller ''[[Speed (1994 film)|Speed]]'', with [[Keanu Reeves]], as one of the passengers of a city bus containing a bomb. She came to read for ''Speed'' with Reeves to make sure there was the right chemistry between the two actors. She recalls that they had to do "all these really physical scenes together, rolling around on the floor and stuff."<ref>{{cite news| last = Svetkey| first = Benjamin| title = Overdrive| work = [[Entertainment Weekly]] | date = July 22, 1994 | url = http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,303034,00.html | accessdate = 9 April 2009 }}</ref> ''Speed'' garnered acclaim from critics who, according to [[Rotten Tomatoes]], asserted it was a "terrific popcorn thriller" with "outstanding performances from Keanu Reeves, [[Dennis Hopper]], and Sandra Bullock".<ref>https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/speed_1994</ref> It took in US$350 million worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=speed.htm|title=Speed|website=Box Office Mojo|accessdate=October 20, 2015}}</ref><ref name=bom/>
A string of film successes followed ''Speed'', and Bullock soon established herself as a Hollywood leading actress. In the romantic comedy ''[[While You Were Sleeping (film)|While You Were Sleeping]]'' (1995), she potrayed a lonely [[Chicago Transit Authority]] token collector who saves the life of a man. While the film made US$182 million globally, it received positive reviews, with Rotten Tomatoes' critical consensus reading: "''While You Were Sleeping'' is built wholly from familiar ingredients, but assembled with such skill — and with such a charming performance from Sandra Bullock — that it gives formula a good name".<ref>https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/while_you_were_sleeping/</ref> She received her first [[Golden Globe Award|Golden Globe Award nomination]] for [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Comedy or Musical|Best Actress – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy]]. In 1995, Bullock also starred in the thriller ''[[The Net (1995 film)|The Net]]'' (1995), as a computer programmer who stumbles upon a conspiracy, putting her life and the lives of those around her in great danger. [[Owen Gleiberman]], writing for ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'', complimented her performance, saying "Bullock pulls you into the movie. Her overripe smile and clear, imploring eyes are sometimes evocative of [[Julia Roberts]]".<ref>{{cite web | date = August 4, 1995 | author = Owen Gleiberman | title = 'The Net' review at EW | url = http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,298206,00.html | accessdate = 23 August 2010 }}</ref> ''The Net'' made US$110.6 million.<ref>https://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=net.htm</ref>
In the crime drama ''[[A Time to Kill (1996 film)|A Time to Kill]]'' (1996), Bullock portrayed a member of the defense team in the trial for murder of a young girl, opposite [[Samuel L. Jackson]], [[Matthew McConaughey]] and [[Kevin Spacey]]. She received a [[MTV Movie Award]] nomination for Best Breakthrough Performance. The film grossed US$152 million around the world.<ref>https://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=timetokill.htm</ref> Bullock subsequently received US$11 million for the critically panned ''[[Speed 2: Cruise Control]]'' (1997), which she agreed to star in for financial backing for her next project, ''[[Hope Floats]]'' (1998).<ref>[http://www.damascusfest.com/en/film/details/Speed+2%3A+Cruise+Control/214 "Festival History: 1987: ''Speed 2: Cruise Control''"]{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, [[Damascus International Film Festival]] XVIII, November 7–13, 2010 {{Dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> She has stated that she regrets making the sequel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nation.com.pk/entertainment/21-May-2009/Sandra-regrets-making-Speed-2|title=Sandra regrets making Speed 2|publisher=Nation}}</ref> In ''Hope Floats'', she starred as an unassuming housewife whose life is disrupted when her husband (played by [[Michael Paré]]) reveals his infidelity to her on a talk show. While the film made US$81.4 million,<ref>https://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=hopefloats.htm</ref> critic [[James Berardinelli]], in his review, remarked that she is "better suited to more lighthearted fare".<ref>{{cite web|last=Berardinelli|first=James|authorlink=James Berardinelli|title=Review: Hope Floats|url=http://www.reelviews.net/movies/h/hope.html|website=[[ReelViews]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070205103701/http://www.reelviews.net/movies/h/hope.html|archivedate=February 5, 2007|year=1998|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref>
The comedy ''[[Practical Magic]]'' (1998) saw her star with [[Nicole Kidman]], as two witch sisters who face a curse which threatens to prevent them ever finding lasting love. While the film opened atop on its North American opening weekend, it flopped at the box office.<ref>https://www.the-numbers.com/movie/Practical-Magic#tab=summary</ref> In 1998, she also provided the voice of in the animated aventure film ''[[The Prince of Egypt]]'', and wrote, produced and directed the short film ''[[Making Sandwiches]]''. She played a free-spirited drifter who begins to talk to a writer in the 1999 romantic comedy ''[[Forces of Nature (1999 film)|Forces of Nature]]'', alongside [[Ben Affleck]]. The film was a commercial hit, grossing US$93 million worldwide,<ref>https://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=forcesofnature.htm</ref> and ''Boxoffice Magazine'' remarked: "The combination of Affleck's deadpan by-the-book persona with the spontaneity of Bullock's character sparks with convincing chemistry, their diverse personalities causing both to grow and bring to the surface what each is running away from or can't admit".<ref>https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/forces_of_nature/reviews/</ref>
===Established career (2000–2008)=== Bullock took on the role of a [[FBI]] agent, who must go undercover in the Miss United States beauty pageant to prevent a group from bombing the event, in the comedy ''[[Miss Congeniality (film)|Miss Congeniality]]'' (2000). It was a financial success, grossing US$212 million worldwide,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=misscongeniality.htm |title=Miss Congeniality (2000) |publisher=Box Office Mojo|accessdate=October 15, 2013}}</ref> and earned Bullock another Golden Globe Award nomination for Best Actress – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy. In 2000, she also played a newspaper columnist obliged to enter [[Drug rehabilitation|rehabilitation]] for alcoholism in the dramedy ''[[28 Days (film)|28 Days]]'', which was a moderate commercial success, with a global gross of US$62.1 million.<ref>https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0191754/</ref> Bullock produced the romantic comedy ''[[Kate & Leopold]]'', released in 2001, which she followed with acting work in the psychological thriller ''[[Murder by Numbers]]'' (2002), portraying a seasoned homicide detective. [[Roger Ebert]] awarded the film three stars out of a possible four, stating: "Bullock does a good job here of working against her natural likability, creating a character you'd like to like, and could like, if she weren't so sad, strange and turned in upon herself."<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/murder-by-numbers-2002 |last= Ebert |first= Roger |authorlink= Roger Ebert |date= April 19, 2002 |title= ''Murder by Numbers'' |publisher= rogerebert.com |accessdate= December 14, 2015}}</ref> [[File:Sandra Bullock(cannesPhotoCall).jpg|upright|Bullock at the [[Cannes Film Festival]] in 2002|thumb]] Bullock teamed up with [[Hugh Grant]] for the romantic comedy ''[[Two Weeks Notice]]'' (2002),<ref>{{cite web|title=Sandra Bullock and Hugh Grant Talk About 'Two Weeks Notice'|url=http://movies.about.com/library/weekly/aa121902a.htm|publisher=[[About.com]]|accessdate=July 8, 2013}}</ref> in which she starred as a lawyer who walks out on her boss. Liz Braun, of ''Jam! Movies'', found Bullock and Grant to be "perfectly paired", stating: "The script allows the two actors to be at their comedic best, even though the film as a whole is amateurish in many ways".<ref>http://jam.canoe.ca/Movies/Reviews/</ref> ''Two Weeks Notice'' made US$199 million globally.<ref>https://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=twoweeksnotice.htm</ref> She was presented with the [[Raúl Juliá]] Award for Excellence in 2002,<ref>{{cite web|last=Shor |first=Donna |title=Around Town |publisher=Washington Life Magazine |date=November 2002 |url=http://www.washingtonlife.com/backissues/archives/02nov/around_town.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20031225071915/http://www.washingtonlife.com/backissues/archives/02nov/around_town.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=December 25, 2003 |accessdate=February 5, 2007 |df=}}</ref> for her efforts, as the executive producer of the sitcom ''[[George Lopez (TV series)|George Lopez]]'' (2002–07), in helping expand career openings for Hispanic talent in the media and entertainment industry. She also made several appearances on the show as [[List of George Lopez characters#Accident Amy|Accident Amy]], an accident-prone employee at the factory Lopez's character manages.
Bullock made part of a large ensemble cast, playing the wife of a district attorney, in the drama ''[[Crash (2004 film)|Crash]]'' (2004), which won the [[Academy Award for Best Picture]]. She received positive reviews for her performance, with some critics suggesting that it was the best performance of her career.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/10010458-proposal/news/1827544/2/total_recall_sandra_bullocks_best_movies|title=Total Recall: Sandra Bullock's Best Movies|last=Giles|first=Jeff|date=June 18, 2009| work = IGN Entertainment|page=2|accessdate=January 6, 2010}}</ref> In 2005, she received a US$17.5 million salary for ''[[Miss Congeniality 2: Armed and Fabulous]]'',<ref>{{cite news|last=Hornaday|first=Ann|title=Miss Congeniality' Sequel Flunks the Talent Competition|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A61702-2005Mar23.html|work=The Washington Post|date= March 24, 2005|accessdate=August 11, 2012}}</ref> and was a co-recipient of the [[Women in Film Crystal + Lucy Awards|Women in Film]] [[Women in Film Crystal + Lucy Awards#THE CRYSTAL AWARD|Crystal Award]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://womeninfilm.org/the-crystal-lucy-awards/|title=" The Crystal + Lucy Awards®}}</ref> In the romantic drama ''[[The Lake House (film)|The Lake House]]'' (2006), Bullock reunited with [[Keanu Reeves]], despite that their characters are separated throughout the film; they were only on set together for two weeks during filming.<ref>{{cite web |last=Topel |first=Fred |work=The Wave Magazine |title=Speed Demons |url=http://www.thewavemag.com/pagegen.php?pagename=article&articleid=25895 |accessdate=June 17, 2006 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061216071629/http://www.thewavemag.com/pagegen.php?pagename=article&articleid=25895 |archivedate =December 16, 2006}}</ref> The film had a negative critical response, but made US$114.8 million.<ref>https://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=lakehouse.htm</ref> In 2006, Bullock also played [[Harper Lee]] in ''[[Infamous (film)|Infamous]]'', a drama based on [[George Plimpton]]'s 1997 book, ''Truman Capote: In Which Various Friends, Enemies, Acquaintances, and Detractors Recall His Turbulent Career''.
Bullock headlined the supernatural thriller ''[[Premonition (2007 film)|Premonition]]'' (2007), with [[Julian McMahon]], as a housewife who experiences the days surrounding her husband's death in a non-chronological order.<ref>{{cite news|last=Whipp |first=Glenn |title=Dead or alive? |publisher=San Bernardino County Sun |date=January 20, 2007 |url=http://www.sbsun.com/entertainment/ci_5046256 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927202825/http://www.sbsun.com/entertainment/ci_5046256 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=September 27, 2007 |accessdate=February 5, 2007}}</ref> Despite negative reviews, several critics, including [[Rex Reed]], commended Sandra Bullock for her performance,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://observer.com/2007/03/i-see-sandra-bullock/|title=See Sandra Bullock!: Gorgeous star has weird visions in so-so mystery Premonition|work=[[The New York Observer]]|accessdate=31 December 2013}}</ref> and the film grossed US$84.1 million around the globe. In 2008, Bullock was announced as "the face" of the cosmetic brand [[Artistry (cosmetics)|Artistry]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Artistry signs Sandra Bullock|url=http://www.thetruthaboutamway.com/artistry-signs-sandra-bullock/|publisher=thetruthaboutamway.com|date=January 25, 2008|accessdate=July 8, 2013}}</ref>
=== Critical recognition (2009–2014) === [[File:SandraBullockMay09.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Bullock at the premiere of ''[[The Proposal (2009 film)|The Proposal]]'' in 2009]] The year 2009 proved to be especially good for Bullock, giving the actress two record highs in her career. The romantic comedy ''[[The Proposal (2009 film)|The Proposal]]'', with [[Ryan Reynolds]], grossed US$317 million at the box office worldwide, making it her fourth-most successful picture to date.<ref name=bom/> She received her third Golden Globe Award nomination for Best Actress role for Motion Picture Musical or Comedy.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sandra Bullock |url=http://www.goldenglobes.com/sandra-bullock |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131216052028/http://www.goldenglobes.com/sandra-bullock |dead-url=yes |archive-date=December 16, 2013 |publisher=goldenglobes.com |accessdate=October 18, 2014 |df=}}</ref> The drama ''[[The Blind Side (film)|The Blind Side]]'' opened at number two behind ''[[The Twilight Saga: New Moon|New Moon]]'' with US$34.2 million, making it her second-highest opening weekend ever. ''The Blind Side'' grossed over US$309 million, making it her highest-grossing domestic film, her fourth-highest-grossing film worldwide, and the first one in history to pass the US$200 million mark with only one top-billed female star.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=blindside.htm |title=The Blind Side (2009) | work = [[Box Office Mojo]]|publisher= Amazon.com |date=February 21, 2010 |accessdate=February 28, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Donaldson |first=Catherine |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20334551,00.html |title=Sandra Bullock Makes History!|newspaper=People|date=January 5, 2010 |accessdate=March 5, 2010}}</ref> Bullock had initially turned down the role of [[Leigh Anne Tuohy]] three times due to a discomfort with portraying a devout Christian.<ref>{{cite web|last=Swartzendruber |first=Jay |url=http://www.crosswalk.com/movies/11616855/ |title=Believers Walk the Talk in The Blind Side |publisher=Crosswalk.com |date=November 17, 2009 |accessdate=March 8, 2010}}</ref> She was awarded the [[Academy Award]], [[Golden Globe Award]], [[Screen Actors Guild Award]] and [[Critics' Choice Movie Award]] for Best Actress.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/news/life-begins-at-45-bullock-wins-best-actress-award-at-golden-globes-1871991.html |title=Life begins at 45: Bullock wins best actress award at Golden Globes |date=January 19, 2010 |work=The Independent |accessdate=January 28, 2010 |location=London |deadurl=yes |archivedate=January 22, 2010}}</ref> ''The Blind Side'' also received an Academy Award for Best Picture nomination.<ref>{{cite web|title=The 82nd Academy Awards (2010) Nominees and Winners |url=http://www.oscars.org/awards/academyawards/legacy/ceremony/82nd-winners.html |publisher=Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006110009/http://www.oscars.org/awards/academyawards/legacy/ceremony/82nd-winners.html |archivedate=October 6, 2014}}</ref>
Winning the Oscar also gave Bullock another unique distinction—since she won two "[[Golden Raspberry Awards|Razzies]]" the day before, for her performance in ''[[All About Steve]]'' (2009), she is the only performer ever to have been named both "Best" and "Worst" for the same year.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE62609S20100307?loomia_ow=t0:s0:a49:g43:r2:c0.156371:b31605058:z0|title=Oscar hopeful Sandra Bullock crowned worst actress|last=Dobuzinskis|first=Alex|agency=Reuters|date=March 7, 2010|accessdate=March 8, 2010}}</ref> Following a two-year hiatus from the screen, Bullock starred alongside [[Tom Hanks]], as a widow of the [[September 11 attacks]], in the drama ''[[Extremely Loud & Incredibly Close (film)|Extremely Loud & Incredibly Close]]'', a film adaptation based on the [[Extremely Loud & Incredibly Close|novel of the same name]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Extremely Loud & Incredibly Close (2011)|url=https://movies.nytimes.com/2011/12/23/movies/extremely-loud-incredibly-close-with-tom-hanks-review.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|accessdate=June 20, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=December 22, 2011}}</ref> Despite mixed reviews,<ref>{{cite web|title=Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/extremely-loud-and-incredibly-close|publisher=Metacritic|accessdate=June 20, 2013}}</ref> the film was nominated for numerous awards, including an Academy Award for Best Picture nomination.
